abstract: Ultramet, Inc. has spurred a new process for producing rocket engine thrust chambers, through SBIR funding and the Glenn Research Center. High-temperature oxidation-resistant thruster materials are being produced in order to achieve high-temperature capability without sacrificing reliability. These thruster materials lead to an estimated three-percent improvement in propulsion system performance. To develop this material, Ultramet used a process called chemical vapor deposition (CVD). CVD involves heating precursors for metals, like iridium and rhenium, to temperatures at which they become gaseous. They are then deposited onto a mandrel, or spindle, layer-by-layer to produce high-density, highly resistant materials from the inside out.
title: Giving Bigger Satellites a Boost
